content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the Act. It aims to improve the coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 focuses on consolidating export promotion activities, clarifying roles of committee members, and improving export information platforms. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to improve Export.gov as a single window for export information and develop a single window for export control compliance. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for promoting exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. It also aims to consolidate duplicative export promotion activities and provide information about trade missions and trade fairs. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include identifying opportunities for consolidating or co-locating offices of agencies involved in export financing activities and enhancing the use of electronic databases for resource allocation. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include providing detailed information on Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities to better serve United States businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make this information available. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to provide detailed information on trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. The amendment includes describing the goals and objectives of the department or agency, explaining the rationale for measuring and reporting on those goals and objectives, and involving Congress in the process. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of TPCC members in export promotion and financing activities. The amendment includes recommendations from the Comptroller General for coordination and updates the reference to the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress on the activities of the TPCC. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, and the implementation of specific sections of the FREEDOM Support Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the extent of funding for export promotion activities and the interagency working groups on energy of the TPCC. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce submits an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the TPCC's performance and implementation of its strategic plan. The Department of Commerce consults with the inspector general of other Federal departments in the TPCC. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' includes the Committee on Appropriations, Commerce, Science, and Transportation, Finance, Foreign Relations, and Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate. The appropriate congressional committees include the Committee on Finance, Foreign Relations, and Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate, as well as the Committee on Appropriations, Energy and Commerce, Financial Services, Foreign Affairs, Small Business, and Ways and Means of the House of Representatives. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for U.S. exporters. The curr_chunk provides a resource for exporters in the United States to submit required information to the Federal Government. Small business concerns and various entities are specified for this purpose. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report within 180 days of the Act's enactment, assessing the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations, and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives related to commerce, science, small business, and entrepreneurship. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
(1) "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator.
(2) "Region of the Administration" is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act.
(3) "Small business concern" is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. Amends the Small Business Act to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting as a business opportunity for small businesses. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers or international clients. At least one matchmaking event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events required under the Small Business Act. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. The authority of the Administrator under this section shall terminate on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
